VR252004_rubric_category_5.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d:
The response does not identify and does not describe one method that emerged during the Green Revolution that would not contribute to air pollution but has negatively impacted soil erosion, such as any of the following:

· Increase in irrigation techniques (increased use of flood or furrow irrigation) can increase the amount of runoff, increasing soil erosion.

· Use of tillers or increased tilling increases soil erosion as soil is disturbed before planting.

· Monoculture farming is the practice of planting the same crop on the same area of land year after year. This practice depletes soil of nutrients (chemical soil erosion) and reduces organic matter in soil, altering soil structure and composition, making it more prone to erosion.

· Multi-cropping or double-cropping involves growing two or more crops in succession, one after the other, which typically depletes soil of nutrients (chemical erosion) and may weaken soil structure, making it more prone to erosion.

o.d:
The response does not explain why a power company would choose wind energy rather than hydroelectric energy to replace electricity generation by fossil fuels, such as any of the following:

· The initial investment for wind energy is lower because wind energy turbine production and installation is less expensive than site-specific hydroelectric dam construction.

· Hydroelectric energy requires a river, which limits where the power company can build dams, whereas wind turbines can be placed in a wider range of locations, giving the power company more options.

· Hydroelectric energy facilities can be impacted by drought, so in regions where long-term climate conditions include both ample winds and periodic drought, the power company would choose wind energy as a more consistent/reliable source of energy than hydroelectric power.

· Hydroelectric power plants can impact water flow/riparian habitats/aquatic environments whereas wind turbines do not so a power company in a region with high value aquatic areas would likely choose wind power.

· As wind energy becomes more and more prevalent (in demand), the cost of building, installing and maintaining will be less than old technologies such as hydroelectric making wind a better financial choice for the power company.

o.d:
The response does not explain why a power company would choose wind energy rather than solar energy to replace electricity generation by fossil fuels, such as any of the following:

· Wind energy can generate power 24 hours a day while solar panels can generate power only during daylight hours, so they provide a potentially more continuous source of power than solar panels.

· The power company would consider availability of sunlight vs. wind in a local climate, so in areas where wind is a more consistent source of energy than sunlight, wind energy would provide a more consistent power supply.

· The initial investment for wind energy is lower because wind energy turbine production and installation is less expensive than solar panel production and installation in many cases based on the materials needed to construct a solar panel.

· The power company would need to acquire less land for wind turbines than solar energy farms, which require a large area to collect sunlight.

· Wind energy is more efficient than solar energy because the conversion rate for solar panels is low compared to a wind turbine.
